subject: Re: [junit] Why dont we have an option like Assert.assertIsEmpty() in JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Why would you want that? Do you write your own collections you want to test? If yes, why not use the java.util ones? Or do you test these? If yes, why? If
messageBody:
On Tuesday 24 January 2006 22:42, anish ephrem wrote:
> I am new to JUnit . In one of my test program using JUnit, i want to
> check wheather a collection is empty or not. I am not able to find out
> a proper method (Assert) that helps to check wheather the collection
> is empty or not.

Why would you want that? Do you write your own collections you want to
test? If yes, why not use the java.util ones? Or do you test these? If
yes, why?

If you are testing some other code that returns collections, you can use
assertTrue on .isEmpty() or assertEquals on .size() as David suggested.

You can even write your own assertEmpty that does the above internally.

Cheers,

Robert
